stream_context.summary: Kaze implemented and debugged several dynamic, animated star select screens designed by artist Biobak. The stream focused heavily on technical problem-solving, such as working within N64 hardware limitations, implementing animations with C code, and managing rendering layers to achieve the desired visual effects.

development_findings.summary: The N64 hardware has a strict coordinate limit of ~32,767 units. This technical constraint forced Kaze to redesign a long, scrolling star select screen to prevent the game from crashing.
development_findings.quote: If you render any object out of this range your N64 is just gonna crash.

development_findings.summary: Kaze prefers to write custom C code for complex animations, such as moving a minecart along a spline, rather than relying on external animation exporting tools, giving him more direct control.
development_findings.quote: Why would we use Cozy's object exporting tool if we could just like make the spline points a thing and move it along the spline points?

development_findings.summary: A contributor named Arctic created a tool (strm64) that saved 1.7MB of ROM space by optimizing looped music files, allowing the team to include more streamed audio than previously thought possible.
To save on the N64's limited Instruction Memory (IMEM), Kaze avoids using standard point lights, instead programming custom workarounds that achieve a similar visual effect with fewer resources.
development_findings.quote: I can just use the original lights to fake point lights.

development_findings.summary: Kaze holds a strong opinion that coding style conventions (e.g., PascalCase vs. snake_case) are functionally irrelevant in modern IDEs with syntax highlighting.
development_findings.quote: If anyone tells you you should do it in a certain way they are 100% guaranteed a fucking idiot.

development_findings.summary: Kaze had to manually fix Biobak's 3D models by removing hidden, unoptimized polygons ('sneaky triangles') and disabling certain material properties that cause rendering glitches on emulators.
Kaze recounts being banned from the SMW Central forums for making a crude joke, offering a brief look into his history and persona within the wider ROM hacking community.
development_findings.quote: I was indeed banned from being based.

context_findings.summary: Kaze reveals his YouTube channel earns very little money (e.g., $6.90 last month), which creates a challenge for compensating contributors, a topic he discusses seriously with Biobak.
context_findings.quote: My YouTube as it is, is already barely even profitable.

context_findings.summary: Kaze is moving into a new house with his spouse, Zeina, and has started a new full-time job as a 3D modeler, marking significant personal life changes happening during development.
context_findings.quote: I do not want to play a video game, I want a second life.

context_findings.summary: Kaze expresses a strong design philosophy, praising the art and music of games like 'Paper Mario: The Origami King' while harshly criticizing its gameplay, revealing his prioritization of mechanics over aesthetics.
context_findings.quote: The artists are so great, the music is so great. It's a shame that the game designers on this game are trash.

context_findings.summary: Kaze consciously limits the game's scope, deciding against adding a 'Yoshi racing simulator' minigame because it 'doesn't fit the scope of this game' and would be 'too random'.
Kaze has to deal with minor community trolling, mentioning a specific user who uses a browser plugin to alter his YouTube video thumbnails and titles on a third-party site.

biobak.summary: Biobak maintains a list of Kaze's 'infamous quotes' to be used for a potential sticker pack, highlighting their humorous and friendly working relationship.
biobak.quote: Every time you say dumb shit.

biobak.summary: Biobak provides the 3D models and concepts for all the star select screens worked on during the stream, including 'Koopa Carnival', 'Mouse Cave', and 'Bubble Dome'.
He actively collaborates during the stream, providing live feedback on things like text centering and suggesting animation ideas for the minecart model.
Biobak brings up the topic of payment, partly as a joke, which leads to a serious discussion with Kaze about financial compensation for his work on the project.

badub.summary: Although not present, Badub is mentioned when Kaze confirms his intention to purchase the music for the game and properly compensate the musician.
badub.quote: That's definitely the plan with the music. That would like buy the music and like pay the musician off.

zeina.summary: Zeina participates in creative brainstorming, suggesting one of Kaze's quotes for a sticker pack and discussing the concept, showing her involvement in the project's creative side.
zeina.quote: I also had another idea for the Yoshi sticker set. What is it? I hate video games.

zeina.summary: Zeina and Kaze have a brief, casual domestic conversation on stream, offering a glimpse into their personal dynamic as spouses who live and work together.
zeina.quote: You also clogged my toilet again.

zeina.summary: She confirms an inside joke about a 'happy happy happy' cat meme is real, reinforcing the personal and informal atmosphere of the development streams.

key_stories.title: Animating the Minecart on a Spline
key_stories.summary: When faced with animating a minecart for a new menu, Kaze chose to program its movement along a custom spline path. Through a process of live coding and debugging, he successfully implemented the complex animation, demonstrating his preference for custom code over pre-existing tools.
key_stories.challenge: A new star select screen from Biobak featured a minecart on a curved track, which needed to be animated dynamically in-game rather than remaining static.
key_stories.process: Instead of using an external tool, Kaze programmed the animation from scratch in C. He defined the track's path as a series of spline points and wrote code to interpolate the minecart's position between them. He debugged issues with the logic by printing values to the screen and later added pitch rotation to make the cart tilt.
key_stories.outcome: The minecart is now fully animated within the star select screen, moving smoothly along the track and tilting on turns. The feature successfully brings Biobak's static model to life and adds significant visual polish.
key_stories.key_quote: Why would we use Cozy's object exporting tool if we could just like make the spline points a thing and move it along the spline points?

key_stories.title: Working Around the N64's Coordinate Limit
key_stories.summary: Kaze discovered a large background model would crash the game due to N64 hardware limits. He engineered a clever workaround by creating a custom fog plane to mask the edge of the world, showcasing a typical problem-solving approach for retro console development.
key_stories.challenge: A long, scrolling background model for a star select screen was so large that it extended beyond the N64's hardware coordinate limit, creating a risk of the game crashing.
key_stories.process: Kaze first identified the ~32,000 unit coordinate limit as the cause. He then engineered a solution by creating a 'fog' plane to mask the cutoff. This required spawning a separate object and debugging its material and rendering properties to ensure it drew correctly behind the foreground elements but in front of the skybox.
key_stories.outcome: Kaze successfully implemented a large, gray plane that renders at the far distance. This solution prevents crashes by hiding the point where the world cuts off, preserving the illusion of a vast, foggy background while respecting the hardware's limits.
key_stories.key_quote: If you render any object out of this range your n64 is just gonna crash. I will have to bring the fog nearer.

key_stories.title: The Sticker Pack Brainstorm
key_stories.summary: An idea for a sticker pack led to a collaborative brainstorming session on stream. The process involved Kaze, Biobak, and Zeina sharing inside jokes and quotes, highlighting the team's fun, self-aware, and highly personal creative dynamic.
key_stories.challenge: The team wanted to create a fun, promotional sticker pack featuring Yoshi, but needed amusing quotes from Kaze to pair with the artwork.
key_stories.process: Kaze asked his stream chat for his 'infamous quotes.' Contributor Biobak immediately revealed he already keeps a list of them. Later, Kaze's wife, Zeina, suggested the quote 'I hate video games' for a specific design, leading to a brief, collaborative brainstorming session.
key_stories.outcome: The team generated several potential ideas for the sticker pack, solidifying the concept. The interaction itself revealed the close, humorous, and collaborative dynamic between Kaze, Biobak, and Zeina.
key_stories.key_quote: I also had another idea for the Yoshi sticker set. What is it? I hate video games.

open_questions.context: Kaze revealed his YouTube income is minimal ($6.90 in one month) and seriously discussed with Biobak the desire and difficulty of providing financial compensation for contributions.
questions: How does the team navigate the financial reality of a non-commercial passion project?
Is there a formal or informal agreement on how contributors are compensated for their time and work?
How does the project's financial situation affect team morale, motivation, and the overall scope of the game?

open_questions.context: Biobak delivered several complex 3D assets. Kaze noted that some models were at an 'insane scale' or contained unoptimized geometry that he had to fix to make them work on the N64.
questions: Biobak, what is your creative process for designing these assets, and how much do you factor in N64 limitations?
How do you and Kaze collaborate on the initial concepts for levels and models before you begin working?
Can you describe the technical pipeline and feedback loop between you creating an asset in Blender and Kaze implementing it in the game?

open_questions.context: When asked about 'Spouse's Comedy Club', Kaze corrected the user, stating it's actually 'Spouse's Magic Show' and confirming it is still planned for the game.
questions: What is the concept for the 'Spouse's Magic Show' level?
What is the origin of this idea and how does it involve your wife, Zeina?
